Accidental release Prevention and Emergency Response policies
The City of Galt has instituted a Risk Management program for the wastewater treatment facility, Galt Wastewater Treatment Plant, as required by the Accidental Release Prevention (ARP) program regulations at 40 CFR part 68, and the California ARP Program regulations at CCR title 19, Division 2, Chapter 4.5.  The Risk Management Program identifies the equipment, procedures, maintenance, inspection, and training associated with Regulated Substances (RS's) handled at this facility in excess of Federal threshold quanties; describes the structured assessment of hazards which was conducted to access possible effects on employees and offsite public and enviromental receptors; provides the results of an offsite consequences analysis; defines a prevention program, an emergency response program, and mitigation measures to reduce the probility and magnitude of accidential releases of RS's; and establishes a schedule of responsibilities for implimentation of mitigation measures and auditing of program elements.  The Risk Management Plan (RMP) is being filed with the USEPA and The Sacramento County Enviromential Management Department, Hazardous Materials Division as required by fedral and state ARP regulations in order to report the elements of the current Risk Management Program and to describe further measures planned to mitigate or prevent accidental release of RS's. 
                                                                                                                                   
Stationary Source and Regulated SubstancesHandled
The City of Galt's Wastewater Treeatment Plant is located at 10059 Twin Cities Road, Galt CA in Sacramento County.  The plant uses Chlorine and Sulfur Dioxide in quanties greater than the Federal threshold quantity for this RS.  The facility is located in a rural area north of the city.  There are 6 full time employees at this site.  Chlorine and Sulfur Dioxide are receive

d in one ton containers by truck, handled with an electric hoist, and stored on ton container scales and storage trunions inside the building.  The Chlorine is used for odor control of the influent wastewater, to disinfect the wastewater effluent, and for other process usses.  The Sulfur Dioxide is used to dechlorinate the disinfected effluent for aquatic toxicity control between November 1st and April 30th.  Pressurized Chlorine and Sulfur Dioxide gas within ton containers is withdrawn under pressure and piped to a Vacuum regulator valve located in the storage room where the gas pressure is reduced to vacuum.  From there, the chlorine or sulfur dioxide under vacuum is metered through rate valves and rotometers in chlorinators or sulfonators located in a seprate room, and drawn into water solution by the passage of pressurized water through an injector. 
                                                            
General Accidental  release Prevention Programs
General accidential release prevention programs instituted by the City of Galt are categorized as administrative )management) programs; procedures, training, and engineering controls; and emergency response programs.  The City of Galt has instituted  a process safety management (PSM) Program meeting OSHA requirements at 29 CFR 1910.119 and Cal OSHA general industral Safety Orders Section 5189 covering its disenfection and dechlorination process.  As part of the PSM the City of Galt has site specific Illness and Injury Prevention Plan (IIPP) for the Wastewater Treatment Plant.  The site specific IIPP includes detailed procedures for lockout/tag out, cinfined space, chlorine and sulfur dioxide safety, emergency response and respriator protection.  Additionally operation and maintenance procedures involving chlorine and sulfur dioxide equipment are preformed annually.  These plans and programs combined. Constitutes the general accidental release prevention program for the City of Galt's operations.

Chemical-Specific Release Prevention Steps
Release prevention steps specific to sulfur dioxide have been identified and implimented.  These include, amung other things, installing hold down straps for ton containers trunions, replacement of outdated sulfur dioxide leak detectors, and creation of numerous facility-specific operation  procedures. 
                                                                                                             
 Five Year Accident History 
There has been one incident involving chlorine gas in the past five years.  There have been no incidents involving sulfur dioxide, and no incidents have resulted in injuries, property loss, or offsite conquences.
                                                                  
 Emergency Response Program
The City of Galt's emergency Repoonse Program applicable to chlorine and sulfur dioxide has been coordinated with the Sacramento County Enviromental Management Department, Hasardous  material Division, the local agency responsible for hazardous materials inventory reporting and release response coordination.  It consists of notification of the public agency assigned responsibility for first response to hazardous materials release emergencies.  First responders have participated with city of Galt personnel in response drills. 
                                                                                                                        
 Planned Changes to Improve Safety
All of the improvements and midigation measures identified in the process hazard analysis which the City of Galt commited to accomplish have been completed.  Any other measures identified by employees during workplace hazard surveys, or as a result of audit activities, will be throughly reviewed and considered for implementation.  A history of all recomme
ndations to improve safety and their current status can be found behind Appendix C of the compliance workbook.
